intro: Cochranea hispidula, commonly known as the hairy cochranea, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its erect, branched stems covered in fine, hairy pubescence. The plant produces showy, tubular flowers that are typically pink or purple in color, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and also covered in a dense layer of hairs. Cochranea hispidula thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or arid habitats.
